meanings.definition: Jazy (noun): A type of dance originating in the Caribbean.
meanings.sent1: At the party, everyone joined in the jazy and danced joyfully.
meanings.sent2: The jazy music filled the room, and people swayed to the rhythm.
meanings.sent3: The jazy competition was fierce, with dancers showing off their best moves.
meanings.sent4: Her feet moved like lightning in the jazy, captivating everyone around.
meanings.sent5: The jazy performance was so graceful and lively, it left a lasting impression.

meanings.definition: Jazy (adjective): Showing great skill or expertise.
meanings.sent1: The artist's jazy brushstrokes brought the painting to life.
meanings.sent2: His jazy craftsmanship was evident in every detail of the sculpture.
meanings.sent3: She demonstrated her jazy knowledge of the subject during the presentation.
meanings.sent4: The chef's jazy culinary skills amazed the guests at the restaurant.
meanings.sent5: His jazy performance on the guitar left the audience in awe of his talent.

meanings.definition: Jazy (verb): To move quickly or energetically.
meanings.sent1: The children jazy around the playground, full of energy and laughter.
meanings.sent2: She jazy through the crowd to catch the bus before it left.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel jazy up the tree, trying to escape from the curious cat.
meanings.sent4: Time seemed to jazy by as they enjoyed the sunny day at the park.
meanings.sent5: The river jazy over the rocks, creating a soothing sound in the forest.
